H0.text: One mole is the unit of measurement defined to be the number of atoms in 12 g of carbon‑12.

H1.text: One quark is the unit of measurement defined to be the number of atoms in 12g of carbon‑12.

H2.text: One joule is the unit of measurement defined to be the number of atoms in 12 g of carbon‑12.

H3.text: One ohm is the unit of measurement defined to be the number of atoms in 12 g of carbon‑12.

A4.text: Before the 2019 revision of the SI, the mole was defined as the amount of substance of a system that contains as many elementary entities as there are atoms in 12 grams of carbon-12 (the most common isotope of carbon).

A5.text: The mole (symbol mol) is a unit of measurement, the base unit in the International System of Units (SI) for amount of substance, an SI base quantity proportional to the number of elementary entities of a substance.
